sources.title: Target for Tonight
sources.description: Title: Target for Tonight Summary: The planning and implementation of an RAF night raid on Germany in World War II, concentrating on a low level mission by a Wellington bomber on an oil storage facility by the Rhine. Directed by: Harry Watt. The planning and implementation of an RAF night raid on Germany in World War II, concentrating on a low level mission by a Wellington bomber on an oil storage facility by the Rhine." /> Actors: Production Company: Crown Film Unit Release Date: 18 August 1941 (UK) Aspect Ratio: 1.37 : 1 a documentary made by the Royal Air Force put audiences in the cockpit of a bomber called "F for Freddie" as it set off on a bombing raid over Germany. Made in Britain by the Crown Film Unit with a cast comprised entirely of R.A.F personnel.

sources.title: TARGET FOR TONIGHT video and audio upgrade
sources.description: This version has better contrast and cleaner audio than previous IA prints. “Excellent propaganda film” “One of the better wartime documentaries” “A great document of World War II” (IMDB reviews quotes). A highly regarded British home front propaganda piece and docudrama of the RAF’s Bomber Command’s planing and execution of a night raid on Nazi Germany. No actors were used. Only RAF personnel appear (see cast note). Unfortunately the success shown did not reflect reality. Due to navigational errors and other factors, in 1941 the RAF’s night raids rarely hit anywhere near their targets. This would change for the better as the air war progressed. IMDB rating 6.6. Directed by Harry Watt. Released in 1941 (UK and US). Complete print. CAST NOTE: Sadly many of the air crew seen in this film did not survive the war. SPECIAL NOTE: In late 1943 the USAAF produced a similar although much more detailed film on daylight precision bombing. It’s available here: https://archive.org/details/TargetForToday1944VideoAudioUpgrade

metadata.Plot: a documentary made by the Royal Air Force put audiences in the cockpit of a bomber called "F for Freddie" as it set off on a bombing raid over Germany. Made in Britain by the Crown Film Unit with a cast comprised entirely of R.A.F personnel.
metadata.Actors: John Cobb, Richard Peirse, Percy Charles Pickard
